What is OpenClaw? OpenClaw is a
self-hosted messaging gateway that
connects to WhatsApp, Telegram, Discord,
etc. with AI coding agents to
essentially have a way to, for example,
control your machine from a remote
distance and write code, do a pull
request or send messages. You can do
anything the mind can imagine with
OpenClaw in essence. And you see here
that I mentioned the word gateway. This
is quite an important term in the Open
Claw literature. Let's read the
definition. The gateway is a single
longunning process on your machine that
maintains persistent connections to
messaging platforms, i.e. the ones we
just mentioned above. So in essence,
this is a longunning process such that
when a message arrives on any channel
that you've configured, the gateway
routes it to an agent that can execute
tools locally such as file operation,
file operations, shell commands, browse
automation, etc. letting you self-host
the entire stack because you own the
connections, the config, and the ex
execution environment. What this means
though is that if you're running this on
a computer for example that's local then
unless the computer is always on then
you can't just have it running all the
time. This is different from anything
that's deployed on the cloud because
when you have something host on cloud
then you just set it and forget about
it. The beauty of open cloud but also a

unless you have it on a server then you

it? It's a Dockerbased isolation tool
that runs in a container protecting your
host system. We set the sandbox mode to
non-main. If you want everyone except
your main session to be sandboxed. If it

So there's three options, session,
agent, or shared. And what this means is
that if you have your life cycle set up
to session, every single session for
every single agent that has a sandbox
will be in a separate Docker container,
which means that they'll be very finely
grained isolated. Then there's agent,
which means that every single agent will
have its own sandbox. And there's
shared, which means that among all of
the sandbox agents, they'll share the
same Docker container. So of course,
this one has less overhead than having
every single Docker than having every
single session be sandboxed. But it is
worth noting that if you do have every
single Docker session sandbox, then
you'll have a lot of overhead in your
